children.value: Get familiar with using the IBM Garage for Cloud Developer Tools

The IBM Garage for Cloud Developer Tools is an environment for developing cloud-native applications for deployment 
to Kubernetes and Red Hat OpenShift. It embodies IBM Garage Method principles and practices for consistently developed 
applications incorporating best practices that increase developer velocity for efficient delivery of business value.
A short video introducing the concepts of DevOps with Red Hat OpenShift

<iframe width="80%" height="500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/GOPWObjFTsI" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Each development team installs its own copy of the Developer Tools environment into the team's account. 
The environment includes several features that support IBM Garage Method best practices for consistent and rapid development of cloud-native applications:
Some of the tools are sourced from the

that can be found in the IBM Cloud. This approach helps assemble these reliable open source development tools into an end to end developer experience that is fully integrated with the IBM Managed Container service.
: The Developer Tools are able to install themselves as a new environment
: A Kubernetes or OpenShift cluster that both hosts the tools and itself is a deployment target for application builds
: Deployment target environments that support the application development lifecycle:
: Cloud services commonly required by cloud-native applications for monitoring, security, and persistence
: A prebuilt, ready-to-run continuous delivery pipeline incorporating best-of-breed open source software tools
: Prebuilt code templates for common application components and tasks incorporating best practices that developers can add to their codebase as needed
: A centralized tool to help developers use the environment's other tools, Starter Kits, and so on
: The tools can be installed into the RedHat CodeReady Containers environment
installs and sets up a new Developer Tools environment after the

,
providing a place for the developers to start developing the

.
The objective is to reduce the time required for a team to configure and prepare their development environment.
The key benefit is to make the end-to-end
consistent across each platform and make the out-of-the-box developer experience as simple as possible.

so unneeded tools can be easily disabled or new tools added.
The combination of tools selected are proven in the industry to deliver real value for modern cloud-native development.
Red Hat Open Innovation Labs CI/CD components
embodies a very similar approach to how they deliver success with OpenShift.
After installation, the Developer Tools environment consists of the following components and development tools:
A set of continuous delivery tools
This diagram illustrates the Development Tools environment:
The diagram shows the components in the environment: the cluster, the deployment target environments, the cloud services, and the tools.
The heart of the the Developer Tools environment is a cluster:
Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud
Cluster namespace that encapsulates the tooling installed in the cluster:
Cluster namespaces for deployment target environments:
The following IBM Cloud services are created and bound to the cluster:
Manage monitoring of apps with SysDig
Secure your apps, APIs and Kubernetes Ingress end points
NoSQL Database commonly used for data persistence
Storage service commonly used for binary content
SQL Database used for structure data persistence
The following best-of-breed open source software tools are installed in the cluster's
Jenkins is a common tool for Continuous Integration
Tekton is an emerging tool for Continuous Integration with Kubernetes and OpenShift
SonarQube can scan code and display the results in a dashboard
Artifactory is an artifact storage and Helm chart repository
ArgoCD support Continuous Delivery with GitOps
IDE for editing and managing code in a web browser
